thread.title: Conway's Cox has one happy return against Huskies
thread.title_full: Conway's Cox has one happy return against Huskies

author: ANDY ROBERTSON
title: Conway's Cox has one happy return against Huskies
text:
Conway's Cox has one happy return against Huskies Posted: October 15, 2015 - 6:57pm By ANDY ROBERTSON LOG CABIN STAFF WRITER 
University of Central sophomore wide receiver and punt returner Brandon Cox can now claims a spot in the school record books. 
In Saturday’s Southland Conference match between the Bears and the Houston Baptist University Huskies, Cox returned a punt 93 yards for a touchdown late in the first quarter, bringing UCA a 13-0 lead. 
The punt return fell 4 yards short of former Bear Johnny Simmons’ school-record 97-yard punt return on Oct. 8, 196,0 against University of the Ozarks. 
However, the psychology major doesn’t take full credit for the play. 
“They [coaches] just tell me to catch the ball and run it,” Cox said. “They don’t ever talk about the other 10 guys that are blocking for me and putting their blocks on the line. I really got the easiest job. So if anybody needs to be recognized, it needs to be the whole punt return team.” 
On the season, Cox has returned seven punts for 119 yards. The 93-yard punt is the longest punt return in the SLC this season. 
Despite Cox saying he has the easiest job, he said catching punts is difficult. 
“People see it on TV and say ‘I could’ve caught that,’” he said. “Catching a punt is an art, just like returning kicks, and it’s a skill you really have to practice every day to hone your skills to be great at it.” 
Cox doesn’t only return punts, as he has 72 receiving yards on 12 catches, which is third-most on the team. 
Cox spent his freshman season with the Arkansas State University Red Wolves but transferred to UCA in the offseason. 
Cox was a top receiver for Conway High School prior to graduating in 2014, so this year is a homecoming for Cox. 
“I just felt like [ASU] wasn’t a good fit for me, but coming home is always a good thing, so hopefully I can further solidify my spot here and help this team win,” he said. 
Because he transferred from a Football Bowl Subdivision school to a Football Championship Subdivision school, he does not have to sit out this season. 
Despite the change, he said there weren’t really any adjustments that had to be made. 
“The thing for me, coming here was learning the plays and then playing fast,” he said. 
Now that Cox is back in Conway, he feels like he has more people around him than just the football team. 
“When you’re away from your family and friends back home, you really only have your football team,” he said. “Aside the brothers on the football team, I can see my real family every day. It’s really my backbone and that’s really my support when I came back home.” 
Cox and the rest of the Bears will face the undefeated McNeese State University Cowboys at 6 p.m. Saturday at Estes Stadium.
